author: treyzania
content: imo we shouldn't think about it in terms of eth2 vs eth1 like that

author: treyzania
content: think about it in terms of what the layers of the architecture actually are

content: there's the consensus layer that acts as a global source of truth about the evolving ledger state, and the execution layer that plays out transactions to actually compute the state

author: 0xmiddy
content:
It sounds to me like y'all are referring to the execution layer as the PoW chain and the consensus layer as the PoS chain. Do I have that right?
If so, can someone clarify what "execution layer" means after the merge and after the PoW chain is phased out?

author: treyzania
content: the state from the pow chain isn't being phased out, pow as a consensus mechanism is being phased out

author: treyzania
content: the state (all the accounts, contracts, balanaces, etc), the "execution layer", is being moved into the (formerly "eth2.0") beacon chain

author: 0xmiddy
content: I see. So over time txn validation will shift from eth1 nodes/miners to eth2 validators? Or does it shift fully on day 1 of the merge

author: treyzania
content: it will be a hard cutoff, where basically the beacon chain shifts around to include a hash of a "eth1" block in blocks, pow stops forever, and the sequence transactions is determined by beacon chain block producers

author: treyzania
content: here: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/merge/beacon-chain.md#extended-containers

author: treyzania
content: it's a little more involved than what I described there but that is roughly the intuition
